summary: Here’s another custom d&d character sheet that I used in a one shot over the weekend. Vendal Ashfoot, dwarf librarian who was...
caption:
Here’s another custom d&d character sheet that I used in a one shot over the weekend. Vendal Ashfoot, dwarf librarian who was drafted as a tactician into the dwarven army. Poor poor Vendal got his brain erased at the end of the adventure leading to a massive defeat for the dwarves.

Still taking commissions on these at £40 each.

summary: The New Shirt I ordered for my Mighty Neiners Jester Cosplay i dont have a group that will be an entire baseball team with me...
body:
The New Shirt I ordered for my Mighty Neiners Jester Cosplay

i dont have a group that will be an entire baseball team with me but maybe someday 

I also just ordered a Traveler symbol that I can wear as a necklace

I have purple ducktape that I will wrap around a large plastic baseball bat that will be painted a different shade of purple 

and of course, I have a wig, and have commissioned some horns! 

for reference, the crossover is with Star Trek DS9, the baseball episode

(also yes, i have the socks and belt, i got those along with the shirt on logosportswear.com. My jester design is HERE, and can be edited so if you want the NEINERS shirt with a different name on the back and in a different color, or no name on back)

summary: There was a thunder storm at the end of camp today during dismissal, and I work with six year olds. A few of them start to get...
body:
There was a thunder storm at the end of camp today during dismissal, and I work with six year olds. A few of them start to get scared because of the thunder and loud noises so I say, “Girls, come sit with me I want to tell you a story.”

The do, and in a huddled cluster where they can all hear me in the already-crowded clubhouse we were waiting in.

So I say, “Has anyone heard of an elf named Keyleth?”

Unsurprisingly, none of them have. So I continue.

“There is an elf named Keyleth who knows all about nature. She can turn into rocks and water and air and fire, she can turn into dragons and fish and tigers. And she also controls the weather. One of her favorite things to do is say hello to everyone, because she wants to be everybody’s friend. When you hear thunder, that’s Keyleth saying hello.”

One of my girls asks, “What about lightning?”

“That’s Keyleth as well, but she’s taking pictures.”

“Why does it have to be thunder?”

“That’s because Keyleth is super loud, and she wants to make sure everyone hears her.”

Another girl chimes in, “She can turn into a dragon? Those are scary!”

“They are, but Keyleth the dragon helps people. But she only turns into a dragon on a special occasion. Remember how I said she can turn into animals? She once turned into a goldfish because she wanted to go swimming.”

“Oh that’s kinda cool!”

Some of my girls were still scared, which I get, but they enjoyed the story and I think a few of them want to know more about Keyleth, or Kiki, the Nature Elf.

tags: excuse that i couldn't wait till i got home
this is my first critrole fic go easy
summary: Yasha was in the cage closest when it happened. The Iron Shepherds learned quickly to keep her, Jester, and Fjord apart. The...
body:
Yasha was in the cage closest when it happened. The Iron Shepherds learned quickly to keep her, Jester, and Fjord apart. The other two had been placed elsewhere, and in being packed in for the day’s journey she had since lost track of them. She could see Nott, scrabbling on the opposite side of the cart, two full cages at least between the two of them and a gag in Yasha’s mouth even if she’d wanted to call out. Nott was too busy with locks and hiding to see her, but Yasha was too busy watching as Lorenzo drove a glave through the chest of one of the first friends she’d ever known. Molly had collapsed against the side of the wagon before the slavedriver could even land the first blow, his blood magic sapping the last of his energy and sending him swooning, only woken by the steel and the cold and the blood.

Molly used his last moment to spit blood in Lorenzo’s face, and Yasha felt a bittersweet pride in knowing she would have done the same.

He was close, so close, red eyes open and staring at nothing. She looked through the illusion hiding the cart, watched and waited, and when Lorenzo turned his back she reached through the bars as well as she could with bound wrists and clutched her friend by the colorful robes that were becoming more scarlet by the moment.

The storm had been brewing for days. Small prayers, persistent hope, never failing faith. When she’d been captured there had been not a cloud in the sky. She’d been alone.

She was alone no longer.

The Stormlord did not take kindly to his followers being held captive, and between Him, Jester’s mysterious Traveller (the tiefling was always whispering to someone in the nights, earning swift reprimands, and a green cloak had once flickered out of sight as they pushed through the verdant forests), and whatever old and ancient being that kept Fjord in its sights (and kept causing persistent saltwater rust to bloom across Fjord’s cage, despite how many times he’d been moved to new ones) she could feel the omens of things greater than mere mortals coming for what was theirs.

The storm swelled above, a promise of rescue. People were shouting and screaming and pleading. Nott had lept off the cage behind her and was running for relative safety, Beau had lit Lorenzo on fire before doing the same. Her friends were recognizing a losing fight and retreating while they could. Yasha gripped the robes tighter, closing her eyes and praying.

Not here, not now, not him, she prayed to the clouds above. Leave me for now. I will survive. Spare him instead.

In the distance, thunder rumbled. The storm made threats, offering to break upon them like a wave, but still it held. Lorenzo shouted to his followers. The cart lurched and pulled. She held to Molly until he slipped through her fingers- a golden bauble pulling from the fabric of his robe and staying safe between her worn hands.

The caravan moved with no sense of urgency. A point had been made, and the Iron Shepherds were satisfied. The remnants of the Mighty Nein waited in unnatural and heavy silence until they had pulled out of sight to regroup, lick their wounds, and finally to psyche themselves up to approach their fallen comrade, who was laying in the mud beneath a thin coat of fresh falling snow, red eyes closed and breathing gently.

reblog.comment:

The storm had been brewing for days. Small prayers, persistent hope, never failing faith. When she’d been captured there had been not a cloud in the sky. She’d been alone.

She was alone no longer.

The Stormlord did not take kindly to his followers being held captive, and between Him, Jester’s mysterious Traveller (the tiefling was always whispering to someone in the nights, earning swift reprimands, and a green cloak had once flickered out of sight as they pushed through the verdant forests), and whatever old and ancient being that kept Fjord in its sights (and kept causing persistent saltwater rust to bloom across Fjord’s cage, despite how many times he’d been moved to new ones) she could feel the omens of things greater than mere mortals coming for what was theirs.

The storm swelled above, a promise of rescue. People were shouting and screaming and pleading. Nott had lept off the cage behind her and was running for relative safety, Beau had lit Lorenzo on fire before doing the same. Her friends were recognizing a losing fight and retreating while they could. Yasha gripped the robes tighter, closing her eyes and praying.

Not here, not now, not him, she prayed to the clouds above. Leave me for now. I will survive. Spare him instead.

In the distance, thunder rumbled. The storm made threats, offering to break upon them like a wave, but still it held. Lorenzo shouted to his followers. The cart lurched and pulled. She held to Molly until he slipped through her fingers- a golden bauble pulling from the fabric of his robe and staying safe between her worn hands.

The caravan moved with no sense of urgency. A point had been made, and the Iron Shepherds were satisfied. The remnants of the Mighty Nein waited in unnatural and heavy silence until they had pulled out of sight to regroup, lick their wounds, and finally to psyche themselves up to approach their fallen comrade, who was laying in the mud beneath a thin coat of fresh falling snow, red eyes closed and breathing gently.

trail.content_raw:
Yasha was in the cage closest when it happened. The Iron Shepherds learned quickly to keep her, Jester, and Fjord apart. The other two had been placed elsewhere, and in being packed in for the day’s journey she had since lost track of them. She could see Nott, scrabbling on the opposite side of the cart, two full cages at least between the two of them and a gag in Yasha’s mouth even if she’d wanted to call out. Nott was too busy with locks and hiding to see her, but Yasha was too busy watching as Lorenzo drove a glave through the chest of one of the first friends she’d ever known. Molly had collapsed against the side of the wagon before the slavedriver could even land the first blow, his blood magic sapping the last of his energy and sending him swooning, only woken by the steel and the cold and the blood.

Molly used his last moment to spit blood in Lorenzo’s face, and Yasha felt a bittersweet pride in knowing she would have done the same.

He was close, so close, red eyes open and staring at nothing. She looked through the illusion hiding the cart, watched and waited, and when Lorenzo turned his back she reached through the bars as well as she could with bound wrists and clutched her friend by the colorful robes that were becoming more scarlet by the moment.

The storm had been brewing for days. Small prayers, persistent hope, never failing faith. When she’d been captured there had been not a cloud in the sky. She’d been alone.

She was alone no longer.

The Stormlord did not take kindly to his followers being held captive, and between Him, Jester’s mysterious Traveller (the tiefling was always whispering to someone in the nights, earning swift reprimands, and a green cloak had once flickered out of sight as they pushed through the verdant forests), and whatever old and ancient being that kept Fjord in its sights (and kept causing persistent saltwater rust to bloom across Fjord’s cage, despite how many times he’d been moved to new ones) she could feel the omens of things greater than mere mortals coming for what was theirs.

The storm swelled above, a promise of rescue. People were shouting and screaming and pleading. Nott had lept off the cage behind her and was running for relative safety, Beau had lit Lorenzo on fire before doing the same. Her friends were recognizing a losing fight and retreating while they could. Yasha gripped the robes tighter, closing her eyes and praying.

Not here, not now, not him, she prayed to the clouds above. Leave me for now. I will survive. Spare him instead.

In the distance, thunder rumbled. The storm made threats, offering to break upon them like a wave, but still it held. Lorenzo shouted to his followers. The cart lurched and pulled. She held to Molly until he slipped through her fingers- a golden bauble pulling from the fabric of his robe and staying safe between her worn hands.

The caravan moved with no sense of urgency. A point had been made, and the Iron Shepherds were satisfied. The remnants of the Mighty Nein waited in unnatural and heavy silence until they had pulled out of sight to regroup, lick their wounds, and finally to psyche themselves up to approach their fallen comrade, who was laying in the mud beneath a thin coat of fresh falling snow, red eyes closed and breathing gently.
